header.h2: Information for CCS Students, Employees, and Families

div.h3: Carmel Clay Schools will be closed through the end of the school year

li.a: Indiana Department of Education Testing Information
All Travel Including Spring Break Travel
Cleaning of School Facilities and School Buses
Enrollment of New Students from High Risk Areas
Tips to Protect You and Others from Illness
How to Talk to Your Student About COVID-19

ul.li: School closures and updates will be communicated using the district’s standard channels of communication, including phone calls, emails, text messages and the CCS website.

li.p: To ensure notifications are received, parents and guardians should verify that their phone numbers and email addresses are correct in the PowerSchool Parent Portal.
For phone numbers registered within PowerSchool, CCS families can sign up to receive text alerts by texting YES to 68453.

li.b: All Carmel Clay Schools are closed through the remainder of the year.

div.p: Indiana Superintendent of Public Instruction, Jennifer McCormick, announced that all K-12 school buildings in Indiana will remain closed for the remainder of this school year in an effort to slow the spread of COVID-19.

Our plan moving forward will be to stay the course and continue our current schedule of virtual learning for the six weeks following Spring Break. We also plan to end the school year the week before Memorial Day Weekend making Thursday, May 21st the students’ last day and Friday, May 22nd the teachers’ last day.

While the experts confirm that COVID-19 is a very low risk for students, there is a risk that the spread of the virus is a threat to other more vulnerable members of our community. Social distancing and the elimination of public gatherings has been recommended by the Hamilton County Health Department and other health experts to help control the spread of the virus.

This is a very unusual and challenging situation, but we are confident that our staff and families will work together to meet this challenge and continue to provide our students with great experiences to learn and grow.

li.strong: Virtual learning began Wednesday, March 18th. There will be no virtual learning during Spring Break (April 3 - April 10). .

li.p: Our staff will utilize Canvas and the G-Suite tools for virtual learning opportunities.
Our K-5 students will be engaged in learning activities for approximately 60-80 minutes per virtual learning day plus an additional 10-15 minutes for weekly special area classes.

ul.li: Within the 6-12 grade levels, students will follow their regular scheduled classes. Secondary students will be engaged in virtual learning for approximately 30 minutes per course.

Teachers will communicate office hours to students/families via their Canvas page. During office hours, teachers will be available for real-time Canvas Inbox conversations or through integrated video conferencing calls.
Teachers will be monitoring their Canvas inbox throughout the day to answer questions and provide support for students.
If you are using a personal device at home, test for connectivity and ensure that your student can log in to their Canvas account. For frequently asked questions regarding Canvas, you can click here.

If you do not have access to a device (computer, laptop, tablet, smartphone, etc.) for virtual learning, we will provide a device for your family. To do so you can click here to submit the “Family Mobile Device Check-Out” form.

div.p: Many internet providers are offering free/reduced services for families that do not have access to the internet for virtual learning.

ul.li: 2 free months of internet for qualified families; no cancellation fees: https://www.internetessentials.com/.
Access to Xfinity hotspots for free for anyone: https://wifi.xfinity.com/
$10 per month plans for qualified families: https://www.att.com/shop/internet/access/index.html?source=ECmj0000000000mbU&wtExtndSource=access#!/#%2F
Increasing hotspot data by 15GB on unlimited plans
Access public Wi-Fi hotspots for free
Offering new internet options for low-income households
Adding 15GB of data to customers
Unlimited data for 60 days
20GB per month of hotspot data for 60 days
Free internet for 60 days to households where students reside
Free installation

Carmel Clay Schools will provide your school-aged children with supplemental food during this closure. If you need supplemental food assistance for your student, please complete the form by the end of the day each Monday. https://forms.gle/McM1ro1wcwjDuToe8. You only need to complete the form once to continue receiving supplemental food services.

Next Food Pick Up: Wednesday, April 29th
Pick up window: 11:00 a.m. - 1:00 p.m.
Pick Up Location: Carmel High School, Door #9 Please see Map here: shorturl.at/IOX07
Families are to stay in their vehicles in the Carmel High School carpool line, as the supplemental food packs will be delivered directly to the vehicle by CCS staff and volunteers.
Please click here to view a list of food pantries available in Hamilton County. It is recommended that you call before visiting any of these locations.
Please contact your school's social worker or counselor if your family needs additional resources.

h2.a: Indiana Department of Education Testing Information

div.p: The Indiana Department of Education (IDOE) has announced the cancellation of all state testing for the 2019-2020 school year.

h2.a: All Travel Including Spring Break Travel

ul.li: Students or staff members returning from a country with a Level 3 or higher travel advisory must self-quarantine for 14 days upon return to the US.

As this situation is rapidly evolving, health authorities may also impose international, domestic and/or regional US travel restrictions at any time. Please reference the CDC website on quarantine requirements based on your travel plans.
Students or staff members who return from ANY travel with COVID-19 symptoms may be required to self-quarantine.

All school-sponsored of district-sponsored travel is cancelled or postponed through the end of the school year. The district will re-evaluate all school-sponsored student travel as May 1st approaches.

h2.a: Cleaning of School Facilities and School Buses

ul.li: The district continues to utilize products confirmed by the manufacturer to kill human Coronavirus and other viruses. CCS will continue to clean and disinfect schools, facilities and school buses in alignment with guidance from the CDC.

Custodial staff at all schools are focusing extra attention on sanitizing high traffic areas and commonly used surfaces including counters, tabletops, doorknobs, bathroom fixtures, toilets, phones, light switches, keyboards, and tablets.
Custodial staff are consistently checking to make sure handwashing supplies are checked, restocked and refilled.

Custodians, teachers and staff are all working together to help prevent the spread of germs by continuously disinfecting their classrooms and reminding students about the importance of proper hygiene.

h2.a: Enrollment of New Students from High Risk Areas

ul.li: New families to CCS from countries with travel advisories for COVID-19, should telephone the school for instructions.

br.li: School officials will work with district and community health officials to determine the appropriate registration and attendance plan for those students.
Families arriving from high-risk areas should refrain from visiting the school or district facilities, but may interact with school officials by telephone or email.

ul.li: School facilities are currently not available for use by outside parties.
Carmel Clay Schools continues to be in communication with the Hamilton Co. Health Department on utilization of our facilities by third-party entities.

All Carmel Clay Schools are closed through the end of the year. These closures also include cancellation/postponement of all after school practices, extra-curricular activities, as well as, all school and PTO sponsored events.

h2.a: Tips to Protect You and Others from Illness

div.p: Please remember, the peak of cold and flu season is also upon us and we want to provide you with important tips on how to protect your child and family from these illnesses.

Currently, the CDC does not recommend people who are well wear a mask to protect themselves from respiratory illness, including COVID-19. Masks should only be worn if it is recommended by a health care professional.
Please know that our custodians, teachers and staff are working together to help prevent the spread of germs by continuously disinfecting their classrooms and common areas.

ul.li: Wash hands frequently with soap and water for 20 seconds. If soap and water are not available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer.
Cover coughs and sneezes with tissues or by coughing into the inside of the elbow.
Throw used tissues away in the trash.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, or mouth with unwashed hands.
Stay away from people who are sick or not feeling well and avoid close contact with others through hugging, kissing, or shaking hands.
Disinfect frequently touched surfaces and objects such as toys and doorknobs.
Seek assistance from your doctor or a health professional if you see or experience symptoms that cause concern.
Any student with a fever should remain at home until they are “fever free” for 24 hours.

div.p: Additional tips on how to keep kids germ-free at school can be found here.

h2.a: How to Talk to Your Student About COVID-19

div.p: Concern over this new virus can make children and families anxious. Below are resources how best to talk to your child about COVID-19.

Coping With Stress During Infectious Disease Outbreaks
